ground_truth: At the foot of the cross, Everett snaps its last guy wire with his pincers, and the four men sprint off. As the crowd scatters, the cross descends toward Big Dan, who is frozen, looking up, and it crashes in a shower of sparks and embers that obliterates Big Dan Teague. A car pulls up in front of a town hall from which party sounds filter out, and Pappy O'Daniel emerges from the car with his retinue: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Delmar sulks while Everett is stunned. As headlights play, the men suck back into the alley as a car passes by. The car tools up to the banquet hall, and Homer Stokes emerges with his midget, who tosses his balled-up white hood into the car and both men shrug into their suitcoats; they start up the stairs with Stokes's pace brisk and the midget hopping awkwardly to keep up. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy enter through the back door with the blackface scrubbed off, and all four now wear long gray beards as a disguise, clumsily affixed with spirit gum. Each is carrying a musical-instrument case, and they elbow past the bustling kitchen help. Out in the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit side-by-side at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals, facing the hall with their backs to the stage as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy take their places. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip's chair, draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially, as Waldrip sits stiffly erect, listening, frowning at a spot in space. Suddenly, Waldrip erupts, and she shakes her head vigorously and looks down at her plate as Everett continues pleading to her back. The band launches into "Man of Constant Sorrow," precipitating a huge reaction. Everett, trying to get Penny's attention, is stunned at the ovation as he and the boys, still singing, exchange bemused looks. They shrug and lean into the song with a will. Everett performs an impromptu buck-and-wing, bringing the crowd to new heights of hysteria. Stokes is staring at the band, frowning, while the crowd stares at him, stone-faced, as he plows on. He is hit by a tomato and pelted by foodstuffs, shielding himself with one arm while bellowing into the mike. An old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched before a crystal set, listening to the tinny voice. They look at each other wordlessly and then look back at the crystal set. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his midget looks on apprehensively, and a disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone plug, leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: At the base of the crucifix, Everett cuts its final support wire with his claws, and the four men dash off. As the multitude disperses, the crucifix descends toward Big Dan, who is paralyzed, gazing upward, and it collapses in a cascade of sparks and embers that annihilates Big Dan Teague. A vehicle arrives in front of a municipal hall from which festivity noises filter out, and Pappy O'Daniel emerges from the vehicle with his entourage: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Delmar broods while Everett is astonished. As headlights illuminate, the men retreat into the passageway as a vehicle goes by. The vehicle drives up to the feast hall, and Homer Stokes emerges with his dwarf, who throws his crumpled white hood into the vehicle and both men slip into their jackets; they ascend the stairs with Stokes's pace swift and the dwarf hopping clumsily to keep up. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy enter through the rear entry with the blackface cleansed off, and all four now wear long gray beards as a disguise, awkwardly attached with spirit gum. Each is carrying a musical-instrument case, and they push past the bustling kitchen staff. Out in the feast hall, Penny and Waldrip sit side-by-side at the head table, encircled by the Wharvey gals, facing the hall with their backs to the stage as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy take their positions. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip's chair, draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially, as Waldrip sits rigidly upright, listening, scowling at a spot in space. Suddenly, Waldrip bursts, and she shakes her head vigorously and looks down at her platter as Everett continues imploring to her back. The band starts into "Man of Constant Sorrow," causing a massive reaction. Everett, attempting to get Penny's attention, is astonished at the applause as he and the boys, still singing, exchange puzzled looks. They shrug and lean into the song with determination. Everett performs a spontaneous buck-and-wing, bringing the crowd to new heights of frenzy. Stokes is staring at the band, scowling, while the crowd stares at him, expressionless, as he continues. He is struck by a tomato and showered by edibles, shielding himself with one arm while yelling into the microphone. An elderly man in overalls and his spouse sit hunched before a crystal set, listening to the tinny voice. They look at each other silently and then look back at the crystal set. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his dwarf looks on apprehensively, and a dissatisfied audience member pulls out the microphone plug, leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross, its last guy wire is snapped by Everett with his pincers, and off sprint the four men. As the crowd scatters, Big Dan, who is frozen and looking up, is descended upon by the cross, and Big Dan Teague is obliterated by a crash of sparks and embers. In front of a town hall, a car pulls up, from which party sounds filter out, and from the car emerges Pappy O'Daniel with his retinue: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Delmar sulks while Everett is stunned. As headlights play, into the alley the men are sucked back as a car passes by. Up to the banquet hall, the car is tooled, and Homer Stokes, with his midget, emerges; the midget tosses his balled-up white hood into the car, and both men shrug into their suitcoats; the stairs are started up by them with Stokes's pace brisk and the midget hopping awkwardly to keep up. Through the back door enter Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy, with the blackface scrubbed off, and now all four wear long gray beards as a disguise, clumsily affixed with spirit gum. A musical-instrument case is being carried by each, and past the bustling kitchen help they elbow. Out in the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip are seated side-by-side at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals, facing the hall with their backs to the stage as places are taken by Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy. By Waldrip's chair stands Pappy O'Daniel, draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially, as Waldrip, sitting stiffly erect, listens, frowning at a spot in space. Suddenly, Waldrip erupts, and vigorously her head is shaken, and down at her plate she looks as her back is pleaded to by Everett. Into "Man of Constant Sorrow" launches the band, precipitating a huge reaction. Trying to get Penny's attention, the ovation stuns Everett as, still singing, he and the boys exchange bemused looks. A shrug is given by them, and into the song they lean with a will. An impromptu buck-and-wing is performed by Everett, bringing the crowd to new heights of hysteria. At the band, frowning, Stokes is staring, while at him, stone-faced, the crowd stares as he plows on. A tomato hits him, and by foodstuffs, he is pelted, shielding himself with one arm while into the mike he bellows. In overalls, an old man and his wife sit hunched before a crystal set, listening to the tinny voice. Wordlessly, they look at each other and then back at the crystal set. Almost drowned out by the music is Stokes, as his midget, apprehensively, looks on, and a disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone plug, leaving him to mouth inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross, Everett snaps its last guy wire, and the four men sprint away. As the crowd scatters, the cross falls toward Big Dan, who is frozen, and it crashes in sparks and embers, obliterating him. A car arrives at a town hall with party sounds, and Pappy O'Daniel emerges with his retinue: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Delmar sulks while Everett is stunned. As headlights pass, the men retreat into the alley. The car approaches the banquet hall, and Homer Stokes emerges with his midget, who tosses his white hood into the car. They shrug into their suitcoats and head up the stairs, Stokes briskly and the midget awkwardly. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy enter through the back door, their blackface scrubbed off, now wearing long gray beards as a disguise, clumsily affixed with spirit gum. Each carries a musical-instrument case, elbowing past the kitchen help. In the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals, facing the hall with their backs to the stage as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy take their places. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip, murmuring confidentially, as Waldrip sits stiffly, frowning. Suddenly, Waldrip erupts, shaking her head and looking down as Everett pleads. The band launches into "Man of Constant Sorrow," causing a huge reaction. Everett, trying to get Penny's attention, is stunned by the ovation as he and the boys exchange bemused looks. They lean into the song with enthusiasm. Everett performs an impromptu dance, bringing the crowd to hysteria. Stokes frowns at the band while the crowd stares at him, stone-faced. He is hit by a tomato and pelted with food, shielding himself while bellowing into the mike. An old man and his wife listen to the tinny voice on a crystal set, looking at each other wordlessly. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his midget looks on apprehensively, and a disgruntled audience member unplugs the microphone, leaving Stokes mouthing inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: At the cross's base, Everett cuts the last guy wire, and the four men sprint away. The cross falls on Big Dan, who is frozen, and it crashes, obliterating him. A car arrives at a town hall with party sounds, and Pappy O'Daniel exits with Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Delmar sulks while Everett is stunned. As headlights pass, the men hide in an alley. The car reaches the banquet hall, and Homer Stokes and his midget, who tosses a white hood into the car, put on suitcoats and head upstairs. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy enter through the back, now with gray beards as disguises, carrying instrument cases, and push past kitchen staff. In the hall, Penny and Waldrip sit at the head table with the Wharvey gals, facing away from the stage as Everett and the others take their places. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip, murmuring, as Waldrip listens stiffly. Waldrip erupts, shaking her head, as Everett pleads. The band starts "Man of Constant Sorrow," causing a huge reaction. Everett, trying to get Penny's attention, is stunned by the ovation and performs a buck-and-wing, exciting the crowd. Stokes frowns at the band while the crowd stares at him. He is hit by a tomato and food, shielding himself while yelling into the mike. An old couple listens to the tinny voice on a crystal set, exchanging looks. Stokes is drowned out by music as his midget watches, and an audience member unplugs the microphone, leaving Stokes mouthing silently.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: At the base of the towering cross, Everett deftly snaps the final guy wire using his pincers, and the four men quickly sprint away from the scene. As the gathered crowd begins to scatter in all directions, the cross ominously descends toward Big Dan, who stands frozen in place, staring upward in disbelief. It crashes down in a spectacular display of sparks and embers, completely obliterating Big Dan Teague in the process. Meanwhile, a car pulls up in front of the town hall, from which the lively sounds of a party can be heard filtering out into the night. Pappy O'Daniel emerges from the vehicle, accompanied by his entourage: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Delmar sulks nearby, while Everett stands in a state of shock. As the headlights sweep across the scene, the men quickly retreat into the shadows of the alley as another car passes by. This car makes its way up to the banquet hall, and Homer Stokes steps out, accompanied by his midget companion. The midget tosses his crumpled white hood into the car, and both men hurriedly shrug into their suitcoats; they begin ascending the stairs, with Stokes maintaining a brisk pace and the midget hopping awkwardly to keep up with him. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy make their entrance through the back door, having scrubbed off the blackface, and now all four sport long gray beards as a makeshift disguise, clumsily affixed with spirit gum. Each of them carries a musical-instrument case, and they elbow their way past the bustling kitchen staff. Out in the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit side-by-side at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals, facing the hall with their backs turned to the stage as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy take their positions. Pappy O'Daniel stands beside Waldrip's chair, casually draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially, while Waldrip sits stiffly erect, listening intently and frowning at a spot in space. Suddenly, Waldrip erupts, shaking her head vigorously and looking down at her plate as Everett continues to plead to her back. The band launches into "Man of Constant Sorrow," triggering a huge reaction from the audience. Everett, still trying to capture Penny's attention, is taken aback by the overwhelming ovation as he and the boys, still singing, exchange bemused glances. They shrug and lean into the song with renewed enthusiasm. Everett performs an impromptu buck-and-wing dance, bringing the crowd to new heights of hysteria. Stokes, meanwhile, is staring at the band with a frown, while the crowd stares back at him, stone-faced, as he plows on. He is suddenly hit by a tomato and pelted with various foodstuffs, shielding himself with one arm while bellowing into the microphone. An old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched over a crystal set, listening to the tinny voice emanating from it. They exchange wordless glances and then turn their attention back to the crystal set. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his midget companion looks on apprehensively, and a disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone plug, leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: At the very base of the towering cross, Everett skillfully and carefully snaps the final guy wire with his trusty pincers, and the four men hastily sprint away from the scene in a flurry of motion. As the gathered crowd begins to scatter in all directions, like leaves caught in the wind, the cross ominously descends toward Big Dan, who stands frozen in place, gazing upward in sheer disbelief and shock. It crashes down in a spectacular display of sparks and embers, completely obliterating Big Dan Teague in the process with dramatic finality. Meanwhile, a car smoothly pulls up in front of the town hall, from which the lively and festive sounds of a party can be heard filtering out into the stillness of the night air. Pappy O'Daniel gracefully emerges from the vehicle, accompanied by his entourage: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior, all exuding a sense of importance. Delmar sulks nearby, casting a shadow of gloom, while Everett stands in a state of stunned shock. As the headlights sweep across the scene, the men quickly retreat into the safety of the shadows in the alley as another car passes by. This second car makes its way up to the grand banquet hall, and Homer Stokes steps out, accompanied by his midget companion. The midget casually tosses his crumpled white hood onto the car’s seat, and both men hurriedly shrug into their suitcoats, beginning to ascend the stairs with Stokes maintaining a brisk, determined pace and the midget hopping awkwardly in an effort to keep up with him. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy make their entrance through the inconspicuous back door, having meticulously scrubbed off the blackface, and now each of the four sports an unconvincing long gray beard as a makeshift disguise, clumsily affixed with spirit gum. Each of them carries a musical-instrument case, and they elbow their way past the busy and bustling kitchen staff. Out in the expansive banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit side-by-side at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals, facing the hall with steadfast backs turned to the stage as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy take their strategic positions. Pappy O'Daniel stands nonchalantly beside Waldrip's chair, casually draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially, while Waldrip sits stiffly erect, listening intently and frowning at an indeterminate spot in space. Suddenly, Waldrip erupts in agitation, shaking her head vigorously and looking down at her plate as Everett persistently continues to plead to her unresponsive back. The band launches into their rendition of "Man of Constant Sorrow," triggering a huge and enthusiastic reaction from the captivated audience. Everett, still trying to capture Penny's elusive attention, is taken aback by the overwhelming and unexpected ovation as he and the boys, still passionately singing, exchange bemused glances. They simply shrug and lean into the song with renewed vigor and enthusiasm. Everett performs an impromptu buck-and-wing dance, bringing the excitable crowd to new heights of hysteria and delight. Meanwhile, Stokes is staring at the band with a disapproving frown on his face, while the crowd stares back at him, stone-faced and unimpressed, as he stubbornly plows on with his speech. He is suddenly and unexpectedly hit by a flying tomato and pelted with various other foodstuffs, shielding himself with one arm while bellowing into the microphone in protest. An old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched over a crystal set, listening intently to the tinny voice emanating from it. They exchange wordless, knowing glances and then turn their attention back to the crystal set with interest. Stokes is almost completely drowned out by the raucous music as his midget companion looks on apprehensively, and a disgruntled and impatient audience member yanks out the microphone plug, leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible, futile words.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross, Everett carefully positions himself and uses his pincers to snap the last guy wire, causing the structure to become unstable. As soon as the wire is severed, he and the four men immediately break into a sprint, moving swiftly away from the impending danger. The crowd, sensing the imminent collapse, begins to scatter in all directions, creating a chaotic scene. Meanwhile, the cross, now unsupported, starts its descent toward Big Dan, who stands frozen in place, his eyes fixed upward in a mix of disbelief and fear. The cross crashes down with a dramatic explosion of sparks and embers, completely obliterating Big Dan Teague in a fiery spectacle. Shortly after, a car pulls up smoothly in front of a town hall, from which the lively sounds of a party can be heard filtering out into the night. Pappy O'Daniel steps out of the car with a sense of authority, accompanied by his entourage: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior, who follow closely behind. Delmar, feeling dejected, sulks while Everett stands in a state of shock, processing the recent events. As the headlights of an approaching car sweep across the scene, the men instinctively retreat into the shadows of the alley, waiting for the car to pass by. The vehicle continues on its path and comes to a stop in front of the banquet hall. Homer Stokes emerges from the car, followed by his midget companion, who casually tosses his balled-up white hood into the car. Both men then shrug into their suitcoats, adjusting them as they prepare to ascend the stairs. Stokes maintains a brisk pace, while the midget hops awkwardly to keep up with him. Meanwhile, Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy discreetly enter through the back door of the building, having scrubbed off their blackface. They now sport long gray beards, clumsily affixed with spirit gum as a disguise. Each of them carries a musical-instrument case, and they maneuver through the bustling kitchen, elbowing past the busy kitchen staff. Out in the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit side-by-side at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals. They face the hall with their backs to the stage, unaware as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy take their positions. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip's chair, casually draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially. Waldrip sits stiffly erect, listening intently but frowning at a spot in space. Suddenly, Waldrip erupts in frustration, shaking her head vigorously and looking down at her plate, while Everett continues to plead to her back, trying to get her attention. The band launches into "Man of Constant Sorrow," and the song elicits a huge reaction from the audience. Everett, still trying to capture Penny's attention, is momentarily stunned by the overwhelming ovation. He and the boys, still singing, exchange bemused looks, acknowledging the unexpected enthusiasm. They shrug and lean into the song with renewed energy and determination. Everett, seizing the moment, performs an impromptu buck-and-wing dance, which sends the crowd into new heights of hysteria. Meanwhile, Stokes stands staring at the band, frowning in disapproval, while the crowd turns their attention to him, their expressions stone-faced. As he continues to plow on, he is suddenly hit by a tomato, followed by a barrage of foodstuffs. He raises one arm to shield himself while bellowing into the microphone, trying to maintain his composure. In a different setting, an old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched over a crystal set, listening to the tinny voice emanating from it. They exchange a wordless glance, communicating their shared thoughts, before turning their attention back to the crystal set. Back at the banquet hall, Stokes's voice is almost drowned out by the music, and his midget companion looks on with apprehension. Finally, a disgruntled audience member, fed up with Stokes's performance, yanks out the microphone plug, leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words, his voice silenced amidst the ongoing chaos.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross, Everett snaps its last guy wire, causing the four men to sprint away as the cross crashes down in a shower of sparks, obliterating Big Dan Teague. Meanwhile, Pappy O'Daniel arrives at a town hall with his entourage, Eckard, Spivey, and Junior, as Delmar sulks and Everett is left stunned. As a car passes, the men retreat into an alley, and Homer Stokes arrives at the banquet hall with his midget, discarding their hoods and donning suitcoats as they briskly ascend the stairs. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy enter through the back door, now disguised with gray beards and carrying musical-instrument cases, pushing past the kitchen staff. In the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit at the head table with the Wharvey gals, while Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip, murmuring confidentially. Waldrip suddenly erupts, shaking her head as Everett pleads to her back. The band launches into "Man of Constant Sorrow," eliciting a huge reaction. Everett, trying to get Penny's attention, is stunned by the ovation and, along with the boys, leans into the song. Everett's impromptu dance brings the crowd to a frenzy. Stokes, frowning at the band, is hit by a tomato and pelted with food, shielding himself while bellowing into the mike. An old couple listens to the broadcast on a crystal set, exchanging wordless glances. Stokes is nearly drowned out by the music as his midget looks on apprehensively, and an audience member unplugs the microphone, leaving Stokes mouthing inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross, a symbol deeply resonant in Southern Gothic literature and often used in religious ceremonies, Everett snaps its last guy wire with his pincers, and the four men sprint off. As the crowd scatters, the cross descends toward Big Dan, who is frozen, looking up, and it crashes in a shower of sparks and embers, a dramatic spectacle, that obliterates Big Dan Teague. A car, a classic Ford Model A, pulls up in front of a town hall from which party sounds, reminiscent of 1930s Southern political gatherings, filter out, and Pappy O'Daniel, a character inspired by the real-life governor and flour company radio host, emerges from the car with his retinue: Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Delmar sulks while Everett is stunned. As headlights play, the men suck back into the alley as a car passes by. The car tools up to the banquet hall, a venue often used for political rallies or community events in small towns, and Homer Stokes, a character possibly reflecting populist political figures of the era, emerges with his midget, who tosses his balled-up white hood, symbolizing the clandestine yet public racial tensions of the period, into the car and both men shrug into their suitcoats; they start up the stairs with Stokes's pace brisk and the midget hopping awkwardly to keep up. Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy enter through the back door with the blackface scrubbed off, and all four now wear long gray beards as a disguise, clumsily affixed with spirit gum, a common theatrical adhesive. Each is carrying a musical-instrument case, hinting at their previous musical escapades, and they elbow past the bustling kitchen help. Out in the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit side-by-side at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals, facing the hall with their backs to the stage as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy take their places. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip's chair, draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially, as Waldrip sits stiffly erect, listening, frowning at a spot in space. Suddenly, Waldrip erupts, and she shakes her head vigorously and looks down at her plate as Everett continues pleading to her back. The band launches into "Man of Constant Sorrow," a song deeply rooted in American folk tradition, precipitating a huge reaction. Everett, trying to get Penny's attention, is stunned at the ovation as he and the boys, still singing, exchange bemused looks. They shrug and lean into the song with a will. Everett performs an impromptu buck-and-wing, a lively dance typical of minstrel shows, bringing the crowd to new heights of hysteria. Stokes is staring at the band, frowning, while the crowd stares at him, stone-faced, as he plows on. He is hit by a tomato, a common form of audience disapproval in vaudeville shows, and pelted by foodstuffs, shielding himself with one arm while bellowing into the mike. An old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched before a crystal set, an early form of radio receiver popular in the early 20th century, listening to the tinny voice. They look at each other wordlessly and then look back at the crystal set. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his midget looks on apprehensively, and a disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone plug, leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words.

Each is carrying a musicalinstrument case and they elbow past the bustling kitchen help. Out in the banquet hall. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. Penny and Waldrip sit sidebyside at the head table surrounded by the Wharvey gals facing the hall with their backs to the stage as Everett Pete Delmar and Tommy take their places. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip's chair draping an arm over his shoulder and murmuring confidentially as Waldrip sits stiffly erect listening frowning at a spot in space. Suddenly Waldrip erupts and she shakes her head vigorously and looks down at her plate as Everett continues pleading to her back. The band launches into Man of Constant Sorrow precipitating a huge reaction. Everett trying to get Penny's attention is stunned at the ovation as he and the boys still singing exchange bemused looks. They shrug and lean into the song with a will. Everett performs an impromptu buckandwing bringing the crowd to new heights of hysteria. Stokes is staring at the band frowning while the crowd stares at him stonefaced as he plows on. He is hit by a tomato and pelted by foodstuffs shielding himself with one arm while bellowing into the mike. An old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched before a crystal set listening to the tinny voice. They look at each other wordlessly and then look back at the crystal set. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his midget looks on apprehensively and a disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone plug leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross Everett snaps its last guy wire with his pincers and the four men sprint off. As the crowd scatters the cross descends toward Big Dan who is frozen looking up and it crashes in a shower of sparks and embers that obliterates Big Dan. Teague. A car pulls up in front of a town hall from which party sounds filter out and Pappy O'Daniel emerges from the car with his retinue. Eckard Spivey and Junior Delmar sulks while Everett is stunned. As headlights play the men suck back into the alley as a car passes by. Everett performs an impromptu buckandwing bringing the crowd to new heights of hysteria. Stokes is staring at the band frowning while the crowd stares at him stonefaced as he plows on. He is hit by a tomato and pelted by foodstuffs shielding himself with one arm while bellowing into the mike. An old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched before a crystal set listening to the tinny voice. They look at each other wordlessly and then look back at the crystal set. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his midget looks on apprehensively and a disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone plug leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross Everett snaps its last guy wire with his pincers and the four men sprint off. As the crowd scatters the cross descends toward Big Dan who is frozen looking up and it crashes in a shower of sparks and embers that obliterates Big Dan. An old man in overalls and his wife sit hunched before a crystal set listening to the tinny voice. They look at each other wordlessly and then look back at the crystal set. Stokes is almost drowned out by the music as his midget looks on apprehensively and a disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone plug leaving Stokes to mouth inaudible words.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: At the crest of the mountain, Lester clips its last kite string with his scissors, and the five children fly away. As the flock disperses, the mountain rises toward Tall Sam, who is petrified, gazing down, and it collapses in a rain of dust and feathers that eclipses Tall Sam Thompson. A bicycle rolls up in front of a library from which silence trickles out, and Grandpa Winthrop emerges from the bicycle with his entourage: Paulie, Corky, and Junior. Felix grumbles while Lester is flabbergasted. As taillights flicker, the children sneak back into the tunnel as a bicycle whizzes by. The bicycle zooms up to the theater, and Rufus Stokes appears with his hamster, who pitches his wadded-up blue scarf into the bicycle and both children wiggle into their jackets; they climb the ladder with Stokes’s pace rapid and the hamster dancing awkwardly to keep up. Lester, Jake, Felix, and Charlie slip through the attic window with the face paint washed away, and all four now sport long orange wigs as a disguise, awkwardly glued with paste. Each is lugging a picnic-basket case, and they nudge past the bustling waitstaff. Out in the theater, Molly and Rufus sit side-by-side at the corner table, surrounded by the Jasper kids, facing the seats with their backs to the curtain as Lester, Jake, Felix, and Charlie settle in. Grandpa Winthrop stands by Rufus’s chair, looping an arm over his shoulder and mumbling discreetly, as Rufus sits stiffly upright, pondering, scowling at a point in the air. Suddenly, Rufus bursts, and he nods his head slowly and looks up at his glass as Lester continues talking to his shoulder. The ensemble leaps into "Man of Simple Joy," triggering a massive response. Lester, attempting to catch Molly’s notice, is shocked at the applause as he and the children, still humming, trade bewildered glances. They exchange shrugs and dive into the tune with gusto. Lester executes an unexpected jig-and-jive, elevating the flock to new levels of excitement. Rufus is glaring at the ensemble, scowling, while the flock glares at him, expressionless, as he trudges forward. He is hit by an orange and struck by vegetables, shielding himself with one hand while shouting into the funnel. A young girl in pajamas and her brother sit crouched before a transistor set, tuning into the muffled voice. They exchange gazes wordlessly and then glance back at the transistor set. Rufus is nearly drowned out by the tune as his hamster watches nervously, and an annoyed audience member jerks out the funnel cord, leaving Rufus to gesture unheard words.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: At the foot of the cross, Everett snaps the last guy wire, and the cross falls, destroying Big Dan Teague. Pappy O'Daniel arrives at a town hall with his entourage; Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy, now disguised with fake beards, enter through the back door with instrument cases. Inside, Penny and Waldrip sit at the head table. Everett pleads with Penny, but she ignores him. The band begins "Man of Constant Sorrow," receiving a huge ovation; they enthusiastically continue, with Everett dancing to heighten the crowd's excitement. Meanwhile, Stokes is heckled by the crowd, hit with food, and his microphone disconnected, leaving him mouthing silent words as his midget looks on worriedly. An old couple listens to the broadcast, exchanging a silent look as events unfold.
